title: Revolution of Internet
content: From early broadband adoption to nationwide 5G, South Korea's internet journey is a model of innovation.

timeline.title: Birth of the Korean Internet
details: 15 May: SDN launched by Prof. Jeon Gil-Nam and team — Korea's first internet system.
TCP/IP connection established between Seoul National University and Korea Institute of Electronics Technology via 1200 bps leased line.

timeline.title: Global Expansion through UUCP & CSNET
details: KAIST connected with SDN, forming Korea's first multi-computer network.
SDN connected globally via UUCP: mcvax (Netherlands), HPLabs (USA).
Joined CSNET in Dec 1984, enabling USENET and email access.

timeline.title: Hangeul Creation and Commercialization
details: KAIST developed Korean-language email system.
DACOM-net launched first commercial email service.
Program 'hvi' enabled Korean email communication via SDN.

timeline.title: South Korea Domain Assigned
details: Launch of .kr domain and subdomain rules (e.g., sorak.kaist.ac.kr).

timeline.title: Early Network Developments
details: Joined ACCOM regional network.
HANAnet created via satellite link with University of Hawaii.

timeline.title: SG-INET and Technical Advancements
details: Focus on naming, routing, Hangul, and security.
Led to CERT Korea and KRNIC infrastructure.

timeline.title: First Website and KRNET
details: cair.kaist.ac.kr became Korea's first web server.
KRNET founded to exchange internet technologies.

timeline.title: Commercial Internet Service Begins
details: KORNET (June), DACOM InterNet (Oct), and nuri.net (Nov) launched.

timeline.title: Laying the Foundation
details: 1995: Framework Act on Informatisation Promotion passed.
1996: KII project initiated for broadband infrastructure.
1998: Broadband services launched; 80% household penetration by 2005.

timeline.title: Broadband Boom & Digital Integration
details: South Korea led global broadband penetration.
2000: OhMyNews launched, pioneering citizen journalism.
2002: Seoul named world's most connected city.

timeline.title: Mobile Revolution & 4G Expansion
details: 2011: SK Telecom launched 4G LTE.
2013: LTE dominated mobile subscriptions.
2015–2016: LTE Advanced introduced, prepping for 5G.
2019: LTE accounted for 77% of mobile data traffic.

timeline.title: 5G Leadership & Digital Transformation
details: 2019: First nationwide 5G launch.
2020: Full-country 5G coverage achieved.
2021–2022: Major investment in AR/VR, cloud gaming, automation.
2022: 45% 5G adoption, 22M users, 215K base stations.
2020–2023: 5G-powered pandemic response robots deployed.
2025: 97.4% internet penetration — 50.4M users.

timeline.title: HUBO Introduced
details: Developed by KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science & Technology)
First humanoid robot with human-like proportions
Bipedal locomotion, voice recognition, modular design for research and industrial applications

timeline.title: EVER-1
details: Assistive robot prototype for household and eldercare
Simplified humanoid motions and limited speech recognition

timeline.title: Pibot
details: Educational and social interaction robot
Used in research, competitions, and interactive applications
Improved AI-based communication and multi-tasking

timeline.title: HUBO2+
details: Upgraded version with better sensors, stronger actuators, and improved balance
Deployed in research labs worldwide for human-robot collaboration studies

timeline.title: PIBO (HUBO Educational Robot)
details: Compact, user-friendly robot designed for STEM education and human-robot interaction research
Used in schools and research institutes to teach coding and AI

timeline.title: HUBO-X
details: Next-gen platform with cloud-connected AI, capable of learning from other robots and human demonstrations
Designed for service roles in hospitals and public spaces

timeline.title: EVER Series, M-DRUs, RAIBO, DRC-HUBO+
details: EVER Series – Assistive and companion robots for the elderly (voice interaction, fall detection, medication reminders, emotional recognition)
M-DRUs – Mobile Disaster Response Units built on HUBO platform, capable of entering hazardous environments (thermal imaging, gas sensors, robotic arms)
RAIBO – Quadruped robot for rugged outdoor mobility and payload delivery
DRC-HUBO+ – Enhanced autonomy and team-based coordination abilities, used in Korean government-funded disaster simulation training
